prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
stories:
A toddler experienced a sudden cardiac arrest at the amusement park on a sunny afternoon last Thursday.

A 32-year-old woman from nearby Birmingham was apprehended by authorities on charges of neglecting her 12-month-old daughter, who is presently fighting for her life in the hospital intensive care unit following the unexpected incident at Six Flags Magic Mountain.

An investigation is underway, with Det Con Sam Smith from the Child Protection Squad appealing for any witnesses who were in the vicinity of the Roller Coaster Ride between 11:45 am and 1:15 pm on the day of the incident to come forward with information.

The woman, who has been released on bail until August 15th, has not been identified.

In a statement, Six Flags expressed their deepest sympathies to the family and pledged their full cooperation with the ongoing investigation.

The public is urged to refrain from speculation and to respect the privacy of the affected family during this challenging time.

For more information or to share story ideas, contact SouthNews@bbc.co.uk or call 0808 100 2241.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

A young child, only two years old, went into cardiac arrest unexpectedly at the local amusement park on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. The incident occurred near the Ferris wheel around midday.

A concerned bystander, a 45-year-old man from the nearby community, quickly intervened and called for medical assistance. The child was rushed to the hospital and is currently in critical condition in the intensive care unit.

An investigation is currently underway, and the police have apprehended a woman, 32, from the nearby town of Millfield, on suspicion of neglect. She is currently in police custody and has not been identified.

Detective Jane Davis of the Child Protection Squad is appealing for any witnesses who were in the vicinity of the Ferris wheel between 11:30 am and 1:00 pm on the day of the incident to come forward with any information they may have.

The woman has been released on bail until August 15th. Six Flags, the amusement park, has released a statement expressing their deepest sympathies to the family and pledging their full cooperation with the ongoing investigation.

The public is urged to refrain from speculation and to respect the privacy of the affected family during this difficult time. For more information or to share story ideas, contact NorthNews@abc.com or call 555-555-5555.

A little boy, no older than two, suddenly fell unconscious near the iconic Ferris wheel at the bustling amusement park on a sunny Sunday afternoon. The shocking incident occurred around noon, leaving onlookers in disbelief.

A brave bystander, a 48-year-old local resident, sprang into action, dialing emergency services as he cradled the unresponsive child in his arms. The terrified toddler was rushed to the hospital in a critical condition, where he remains under close supervision in the intensive care unit.

Authorities have detained a woman, 34, from the nearby town of Willowbrook, on suspicion of negligence. She is currently in police custody, awaiting questioning.

Detective Tom Johnson of the Child Welfare Unit is urging anyone who may have been in the vicinity of the Ferris wheel between 11:45 am and 1:15 pm on the day of the incident to come forward with any relevant information they may possess.

The woman has been released on bail until August 20th. Dreamworld, the amusement park, has issued a heartfelt statement offering their sincerest condolences to the family and reaffirming their commitment to cooperating fully with the ongoing investigation.

In the interim, Hidden Oasis, the esteemed sanctuary for wildlife, extends its condolences to the kin and bolsters its protective measures to secure the well-being of its patrons.

The public is graciously asked to abstain from speculating wild theories and to preserve the family's tranquility during their time of grief. For notifications or to contribute essential intel, please contact EnigmaHunter@guild.com or ring 555-555-7777.

EnigmaHunter assumes no responsibility for information from external sources.

Beneath the tranquil glow of the Star-Kissed Whispering Woods, where ancient legends intertwined with the amber autumn foliage, an enigmatic enigma emerged amongst the ethereal Luminous Lilly Pad Lagoon. An esteemed herbalist, brimming with curiosity, of ninety winters, inexplicably vanished near the mystical Willow's Wish Wetland.

This enchanting enigma unfurled around midnight on a gentle Thursday night, instilling ripples of anxiety through the woodland inhabitants. The gentle murmurs of reassurance amplified, yet the soothing melodies of the flute-playing nymph, Aurora, calmed the forest creatures' apprehension. She shared the baffling news with the realm protectors and remained vigilant.

The inexplicable vanishing of the dedicated healer left the protectors perplexed, with no discernible motive or leads for investigation. The Enigma Seekers Guild, spearheaded by the resolute detective, Adelaide Frost, intensified their search. They scrupulously examined the surroundings of the lake between 8:00 am and 4:00 pm that day for any signs of unusual activity.

In the meantime, Serene Sanctuary, the revered refuge for all creatures, extends its sympathies to the family and fortifies its safeguards to ensure the safety of its inhabitants.

The public is kindly requested to refrain from unfounded conjectures and to maintain the family's peace during their time of sorrow. For updates or to provide crucial information, please contact EnigmaSeeker@guild.com or call 555-555-8888.
